conclusion: The working principle of the electromagnetic railgun is that the projectile can move freely between two parallel rails and maintain good contact with the rails. Current flows in from one rail, passes through the conductive projectile, and then flows back through the other rail. The rail current generates a magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the rails at the projectile, which can be considered as a uniform magnetic field. The electrified projectile is propelled at high speed along the rails due to the Lorentz force acting on it.

Xiao Ming purchased a railgun model with the following parameters: rail length \( L = 0.5 \, \text{m} \), parallel rail spacing \( d = 0.02 \, \text{m} \), projectile mass \( m = 0.02 \, \text{kg} \), rail current \( I = 10 \, \text{A} \), and magnetic field strength \( B = 1 \, \text{T} \). All resistances are neglected.

The power \( P \) of the electromagnetic railgun can be calculated using the formula \( P = I \times v \times B \times L \), where \( I \) is the current, \( v \) is the projectile's exit velocity, \( B \) is the magnetic field strength, and \( L \) is the length of the rails.

premise: The formula for velocity in a magnetic field is \( v = \frac{I \times d}{B \times L} \). The given values are \( I = 10 \, \text{A} \), \( d = 0.02 \, \text{m} \), \( B = 1 \, \text{T} \), and \( L = 0.5 \, \text{m} \).
conclusion: The exit velocity \( v \) of the projectile is calculated as \( v = \frac{10 \times 0.02}{1 \times 0.5} = 0.4 \, \text{m/s} \).

premise: The formula for power is \( P = I \times v \times B \times L \). The calculated velocity is \( v = 0.4 \, \text{m/s} \), and the given values are \( I = 10 \, \text{A} \), \( B = 1 \, \text{T} \), and \( L = 0.5 \, \text{m} \).
conclusion: The power \( P \) is calculated as \( P = 10 \times 0.4 \times 1 \times 0.5 = 2 \, \text{W} \).
